conversations.content: Dragons dwell in this land alongside humans. While they may influence the course of history, they rarely involve themselves in the affairs of man.
Dragon law dictates they cannot meddle in the human world without good cause—though they are able to lend assistance so long as no one takes notice.
Deep in the mountains and far from the battlefield lay a wounded soldier. His eyes had been blinded by a blast of magic, and his leg crippled by a wayward arrow.
Any allies who might have helped him had long since fled, vanishing before he even knew what was happening.
Unable to move, he lay in the shade of an abandoned house and prayed the enemy wouldn't find him.
＂Are you all right?＂ came a voice beside his ear.
Blinded as he was, the soldier couldn't see the speaker—but he judged her to be a young girl. When he tried to respond, however, all that emerged was a low groan.
With kind words of encouragement, the girl fed him fruit and gave him water. They passed the day like that, and the next, and then many more.
The young girl's kindness and devotion helped the blind and wounded soldier regain strength.
The soldier thought it strange that there would be a child in such a place, but the mystery of it soon ceased to bother him.
The girl's voice was a light of hope to a man otherwise alone in darkness. Yet all he had was her voice; she never once touched him.
One day, help finally arrived. His unit's leader returned for him, accompanied by a doctor.
The doctor's healing magic restored the soldier's sight. But when he looked for the girl who had saved him, he couldn't find her anywhere.
＂Perhaps it was a dragon,＂ said the doctor when the soldier mentioned it. For he knew of a local legend about a young dragon who helped humans while remaining unseen.
Whenever some small good deed was done—a barn cleaned or a lost item returned—the people of the land knew it was the dragon.
But this time, her act of kindness saved an unnamed soldier's life.
